column33:
Action 3.5. Science Education and Environmental Partnerships -- The district and site leaders took tangible steps to partner with respect to
this action, and additional steps will be taken the following year. For example, we partnered with a climate literacy expert from Fremont USD
for a district-wide professional development workshop this year which was provided for secondary staff. Sites also prioritized science theme
field trips (i.e.Berkeley Botanical Garden (science, grade 1 - includes hands-on exhibits, Point Reyes Earthquake Trail/Nature Walk, science,
grade 4). We are interested in improving climate literacy systems on campuses such as recycling/composting in addition to further
integration across the curriculum. Pg. 52

column33: We enhance our rigorous academic program with a variety of enrichment experiences and activities. Our park-like campuses include gymnasiums, a performing arts stage, outdoor practice fields, libraries, gardens and a natural habitat learning area. STEM, band, drama, physical education, after school sports, enrichment classes, day trips and overnight field trips are a few of the programs designed to create diverse learning opportunities and nurture meaningful relationships with students and staff. - Pg. 1

Expansion of U.C. Master Gardeners program to include all elementary schools, middle school students attending Boys and Girls Club, and the STHS Culinary program; various flora were donated for students to plant at elementary sites, mushroom kits were donated to 5th grade classes accompanying their NGSS (Next Generation Science Standards) instruction about decomposers. Enviro Day held at South Tahoe High School; 280 high school students participated in a range of workshops hosted by South Tahoe Environmental Education Coalition (STEEC) offering hands-on experiences in forestry, wildfire behavior, waste disposal and recycling, tree planting, wildlife sketching, and water quality analysis. Coordinating with STEEC for grade K-5 students to participate in the annual Wonders of Water and Environmental Education (WOWEE) program providing hands-on, place-based learning about water molecules, water pollution, waste sorting, best
management practices, Meandering Meadows, Web of Life, All the Water on the Planet, aquatic invasive species, fish adaptations, microinvertebrates, watersheds, mindfulness art, and photosynthesis; 6th grade WOWEE program teaching students about fire
prevention, Wetland in a Bottle, water quality testing/analysis, planting Sugar Pine trees, and reforestation - Pg. 50

column33:
To support the reduction in absenteeism and meet
the needs of ELs, FY, and LI students through
project-based learning, the district will provide
opportunities for students to collaborate with the
school and their parents on initiatives such as
planting trees and landscaping areas of the
school. Additionally, a community garden may be
implemented.
These initiatives will support Next Generation
Science Standards (NGSS) performance
expectations and will be centered around themes
such as Zero Waste, Water Wise, and Food
Forest. A dedicated Garden Educator will lead
these efforts, delivering hands-on environmental
lessons, nutrition education, and nature
connection activities. These activities will not only
engage students and their families but will also
meet high academic standards, fostering a deeper
connection to school and promoting regular
attendance. - Pg. 137

column31:
Purchase the necessary materials, equipment, and supplies to be able to
provide STEAM Labs and outdoor learning environments.
Outdoor classrooms offer a dynamic and interactive setting that inspires
students to collaborate and communicate. This collaborative learning
environment not only improves students’ social skills but also prepares
them for the collaborative nature of many future academic challenges. In
addition, the freedom and open space of outdoor classrooms provide
students with a sense of autonomy and empowerment, which can lead to
greater motivation. Research has shown that exposure to nature and
outdoor learning environments has a positive impact on student’s mental
well-being and overall academic performance. By spending time outdoors,
students experience reduced stress levels, improved concentration, and

3.25 Support 5th Grade Environmental Science Outdoor Learning Experience - Planned - Planned action for implementation in 2025/26 - Pg. 63  

The school garden provides a
hands-on learning environment where
unduplicated students can engage in experiential
learning, which can be more effective and
engaging than traditional classroom instruction.
Science and Environmental Education: Students
learn about biology, ecology, and environmental
stewardship through direct interaction with plants and the natural world, fostering a deeper
understanding and appreciation of these subjects. - Pg. 137-138

Sustainability Education: The garden teaches
students about sustainability practices, such as
composting and water conservation, fostering a
sense of environmental responsibility.
Connection to Nature: Developing a connection to
nature can inspire students to care for the
environment and make more sustainable choices
in their lives. - Pg. 139

column33: Mattole USD will train its teachers, support staff, and administrators in state academic standards, English language development, science standards, and the district’s approved instructional materials. Staff will also receive training in GATE, STEAM, environmental literacy, social-emotional learning, wellness, restorative practices, diversity and inclusion, and multi-tiered systems of support. In the short term, this professional development is expected to strengthen classroom teaching practices. Over time, the goal is to improve student achievement through more effective instruction and better use of educational resources by staff. - Pg 15

(Part of Study Trips) - Pg 41 Implementing study trips for students across all grade levels addresses the needs of their students by offering enriching educational experiences outside the classroom. These trips provide opportunities to explore new environments, cultures, and learning contexts, enhancing academic knowledge and personal growth. By exposing students to diverse settings and experiences, study trips help bridge educational gaps and promote equity. Additionally, these trips foster community partnerships and collaboration between schools, families, and local organizations, reinforcing the ditrstict's commitment to holistic student development and community invovlemenet with the goal of increasing overall student engagement. - Pg 66-67 District also aims to  establish an Edible School Yard program at all schools, promoting hands on learning, environmental stewardship and healthy eating habits. column31:
Funding for school gardens (included in $25,000): "Provide school gardens, nutrition enhancement,
nutrition related instructional materials, and healthy meals for students." - pg 70
column33:
"A key success taken by our Nutrition Services Department was the effort around promoting health, sustainability, and hands-on learning by launching a districtwide school garden. In addition to supporting more scratch cooking in school cafeterias, the garden serves as a living classroom where students can engage in hands-on nutrition education, learn about food systems, and cultivate lifelong healthy eating habits ... The garden will also double as a space for student-led maintenance and outdoor learning, creating a model of sustainability through school-wide composting and recycling efforts. This
initiative promotes engagement through hands-on, real-world learning that fosters ownership, connections, and healthy habits. " - pg 64 "Garden-based learning has also positively impacted
student engagement, which offers meaningful, real-world connections to academic content and fosters a greater sense of belonging. Educational partner feedback has provided
positive feedback about the hands-on learning opportunities, and several schools have established garden clubs, giving students a chance to connect with peers and adults
outside of the classroom setting." - pg 66

column31:
Outdoor School Experience ($20,000)
Students in our predominantly low income community often lack access to experiences such as outdoor school. By providing sixth grade students with an outdoor school experience, we anticipate that students will be more engaged in our school culture, resulting in increased attendance rates. We also anticipate that an outdoor school experience will motivate students to engage in STEM and Environmental literacy, also resulting in an increase in student achievement. - Pg. 24
column33:
Action: College Field Trips
Furthermore, exposure to varied educational experiences like these has been linked to heightened motivation and interest in STEM and Environmental literacy, which are correlated with improved student achievement. - Pg. 35

column33:
Hands-on Learning: Magnolia Agriscience Community Center (MACC)
Building upon this district-wide commitment to civic engagement and community impact, AUHSD also promotes civic responsibility and environmental awareness through hands-on learning experiences at the Magnolia Agriscience Community Center (MACC). The MACC is an urban agricultural oasis located on the Magnolia High School campus, educating students, families, and community members about sustainable agricultural practices, nourishment, and community building. The Magnolia Agriscience Community Center (MACC) is an urban agricultural hub located on the Magnolia High School campus. It serves as a learning space where students, families, and community members engage with sustainable agricultural practices and farm-to-table nourishment. Through community-building initiatives, the MACC fosters education on environmental sustainability and healthy living. AUHSD students, particularly those in 7th and 11th grades, have the opportunity to explore NGSS Human Impact standards and California Environmental Principles and Concepts during hands-on learning lab field trips to the MACC. - Pg. 17

2. Environmental and Sustainability Education ($286,308)
Provide relevant environmental and sustainability education to promote awareness and understanding of critical issues, empower action, develop critical thinking, encourage stewardship, and prepare future leaders through: Maintaining employment of a District Coordinator of Environmental Literacy, serving under the direction of the Director of Maintenance and Sustainability, to co-lead LBUSD schools in:
-Curriculum integration of environmental and sustainability topics across subject areas
-Project-based learning involving real-world problems
-Field experiences/field trips that directly connect students with the natural world
-Community partnerships and service learning opportunities
-School-wide initiatives, including recycling programs, energy-saving campaigns, and eco-friendly policies to reinforce lessons from the classroom
-Professional learning for instructional staff related to fostering environmental literacy in the classroom
-Nature-centric interventions - Pg. 68
3. Facilities Improvements ($7,531,306)
-Strategically reducing environmental impacts on all District properties - Pg. 104
column33:
FLOW: Elevating Civic Engagement & Stewardship:
The LBHS FLOW (Fire, Land, Ocean, Water) program was designed with the goal of helping students to possess a deep understanding and awareness of our unique natural environment and the value of mindful citizenship. In order to achieve this, the FLOW program is designed to weave together our student body, diverse academic disciplines, and community partners in a communal effort to strengthen our stewardship of our natural environment. FLOW stands for fire, land, ocean, and water--four environmental issues particularly relevant to Laguna Beach.
Students study FLOW topics successively through grades 9-12, having experiences across the curriculum, through a common read, and by attending community partner events. LBHS students now have the opportunity to earn the California State Seal of Civic Engagement and can share their FLOW projects to meet the criteria for this impressive distinction.

column31: District also allocates $137,000 to 'layers of support' which is a fund that is meant to continue student wellness strategies and monitor student outcome data, including integrating Environmental Sustainability in core curricula. - Pg 99 District allocates $2,211,000 towards Environmental Sustainability practices and development - Pg 110
column33:
District aims to build on enviornmental literacy efforts as a focus goal. - Pg 102 District implemented comprehensive sustainability initiatives focused on environmental literacy, facility optimization, resource efficienty and positive climate frameworks. Environmental literacy initiatives and faculty optimization efforts were implemented as planned, though specific metrics for environmental program effectiveness were not fully established in Year 1. Academic performance in science showed positive trends, with CAASPP CAST (California Science Test) scores improving across all tested
grade levels: 5th grade increased from 28% to 30% proficient, 8th grade improved from 24% to 29%, and 12th grade advanced from 21% to 27%. These gains suggest that environmental literacy and sustainability education initiatives may be contributing to enhanced science learning outcomes. District achieved consistent improvements in science proficiency across all grade levels (5th, 8th, and 12th grades), district maintained operational stability while implementing sustainable practices. - Pg 106 Environmental sustainability continues to be a focus across the district. District was on track to spend all $41,000 (spent 96%) but did not spend 4% of the budget due to saving costs on environmental sustainability initiatives, not limited to reducing the districts carbon footprint through energy saving in their MOT department and environmental sustainability practices. Significant fiscal adjustments were made to align with the district's sustainability goals and legal requirements while maintaining educational quality. The most substantial change involved reducing the economic uncertainty reserve from 7% to the legally required minimum of 3%, freeing up approximately 4% of the district's budget for reinvestment in educational programs and facility improvements. These reallocated funds were strategically deployed to support environmental literacy programs, facility upgrades to improve Facility Inspection Tool (FIT) ratings, and enhanced science instruction that contributed to the observed CAASPP California Science Test (CAST) improvements. - Pg 107 District delivered environmental education program implementation, and professional development emphasizing sustainable practices and environmental literacy. *Environmental literacy implementation showed promise through improved science scores, though direct measurement of environmental knowledge and behaviors requires development. - Pg 108 District mentions that environmental literacy program assessment requires more robust metrics to measure effectiveness beyond science test scores. District will expand on these metrics by Building on the positive CAASPP CAST results, the district will develop comprehensive environmental literacy assessments including student knowledge, behavior changes, and community engagement measures. New actions include student-led environmental projects, community sustainability partnerships, and annual environmental impact reporting. - pg 109 District will expand professional development to include sustainability education training for all staf, environmental literacy curriculum development, and facility management best practices. District is also implementing intergrated sustainability dashboard monitoring indicators and outcomes, including environmental education outcomes to allow for real-time adjustments and data-driven decision making. District is allocating $2,211,000 towards Environmental Sustainability which includes: 4.1A Implement Environmental Sustainability scope and sequence of experiences to provide all students with environmental literacy and outdoor learning activities, 4.1B Train TK-5 educators using district science adoption to increase early scientific literacy, 4.1C Maintain energy consumption and waste reduction awareness campaigns districtwide. 4.1D Maintain clean and orderly classrooms and schools to support learning and ensure the safety of students and staff, 4.1E Develop a multi-year Environmental Sustainability Plan to guide ongoing district actions toward promoting district-wide sustainability strategies, 4.1F Continue ongoing bond investments to build upon school gardens, solar power generation, and water capture strategies at every school site - Pg 110

column33: LGSUHSD will transform campuses into Green Ribbon Schools that promote a sustainable environment, nutritious food options, and efficient use of resources. column33: District has a the coordinated Life Lab (school garden) and FoodLab (school meals) programs that have received numerous rewards and national and international attention. Together, the two programs teach students of all ages nutrition, gardening, life science, healthy eating, and cooking skills. The youngest students begin with simple gardening tasks and assisting with preparing and cleaning up healthy snacks and meals. As students grow older they take on greater responsibility for composting, planting, harvesting, measuring, recording, and planning experiments. Finally, in the fifth and sixth grades, students assist in preparing school lunches, including cooking, menu planning, and nutritional analysis. - Pg 4

column31: District allocates $13,194 towards Design and Support Environmental Literacy - Pg 43 District also allocates $5,167 towards Environmental Engagement and Enrichment, and $1,352,673 towards Sustainable School Systems and Environmentally Concious & Prudent Systems - pg 44
column33:
District's 25-25 LCAP focuses on three main priorities, including environmental literacy. - Pg 6 The San Lorenzo Valley Unified School District is located in an area of unparalleled natural beauty and resources. The increasing impacts of human caused climate change have directly affected our community with forest fires and unprecedented winter storms causing school closures. These experiences coupled with the "Blueprint for Environmental Literacy: Educating every California student in, about and for the
Environment'' published by the California Department of Education led us to the development of this goal. Additionally, the Environmental Principles and Concepts are legislated per California Public Resources Code (Section 71301) and Education Code ( Section 51227.3). - Pg 37 The District set measurable goals for environmental literacy and sustainability. By Year 3, 50% of departments at BCE and SLVE and 60% of MS will meet “medium” on the Environmental Literacy Continuum, while HS targets 70%. Schools aim to incorporate Environmental Principles and Concepts across TK–5. Sustainability actions include reducing utilities by 10% from 2024–25 levels, despite baseline increases in water (+2,387 units), gas (+32,500 therms), and electricity (+258,514 kWh). Composting is targeted at 2 cans per day in Food Services and 1 per day at HS. All schools are expected to implement at least 2 sustainable actions in their SPSA by Year 3. Fleet electrification will rise from 9% in 2023–24 to 23% by Year 3. Additionally, 50% of classrooms are expected to participate in the Green Classroom Challenge, 75% of students will report outdoor learning experiences, and 75% will have had Environmental Literacy lessons. Climate change education is a new metric, with a 100% target for students in grades 1–12 by Year 3. – Pg 37–39 In 2024–25, Environmental Principles and Concepts were partially implemented, with professional development provided and leadership teams beginning site-level planning for full rollout. Climate change instruction was also partially implemented, with coursework covering causes, effects, and methods to mitigate and adapt, aligned with AB 285. The 5th grade science camp goal was fully implemented, with all students attending. The Seal of Civic Engagement in Environmental Literacy was only partially implemented, as development of a protocol was delayed by competing initiatives. The Sustainable Schools initiative was fully implemented, with all schools participating in the Green Classroom Challenge and building further systems for environmental stewardship. Campus Food Systems were fully implemented, expanding aquaponics and school garden produce use, increasing scratch cooking, and integrating nutrition services. Facilities maintenance was fully implemented, with all schools inspected to maintain a “Good” or better rating. Utilities reduction was also fully implemented, with monitoring through the Pelican Energy Management System, HVAC upgrades, solar installations, composting expansion, and landfill waste reduction. Finally, electric vehicle adoption was partially implemented, with an increase in the electric monitor vehicle fleet but not yet full expansion. – Pg 41 Effectiveness was mixed. Professional development supported Environmental Principles and Concepts, but a full rollout has yet to be achieved. Climate change education is now embedded into coursework as required by AB 285. All 5th graders attended science camp, but the Seal of Civic Engagement in Environmental Literacy was delayed. Hands-on programs, outdoor learning, and the Green Classroom Challenge showed strong participation, while infrastructure efforts improved efficiency through expanded campus food systems, greater use of local farm products, and facility upkeep. Waste reduction, water conservation, and expansion of electric vehicles also demonstrated progress. Overall, the district’s initiatives were effective in building environmental awareness, sustainability practices, and infrastructure improvements, but some areas such as full environmental literacy implementation and the Seal of Civic Engagement require further development. – Pg 42 For the coming year, the district will refine and streamline initiatives to strengthen progress toward sustainability and environmental goals. Efforts will focus on three key areas: first, designing and supporting environmental literacy by integrating environmental education across all grade levels and subjects so students gain the skills to be responsible stewards; second, expanding environmental engagement and enrichment through hands-on learning such as field studies, student-led projects, and extracurricular programs that build sustainability awareness; and third, advancing sustainable schools and environmentally conscious systems by embedding sustainable practices into facilities, resource management, and daily operations to create environmentally responsible school communities. – Pg 43 The district has three main environmental action areas. Design and Support Environmental Literacy focuses on integrating environmental education across all grade levels and subjects, with goals including curriculum materials and supports, curriculum development, training and professional development, Environmental Principles and Concepts, and the Seal of Civic Engagement. Environmental Engagement and Enrichment emphasizes hands-on learning through field studies, student-led projects, extracurricular programs that promote sustainability and environmental awareness, and Science Camp. Sustainable School Systems and Environmentally Conscious & Prudent Systems aim to embed sustainable practices into facilities, resource management, and daily operations by developing site action plans, improving food systems, supporting sustainable school facilities, expanding use of electric vehicles, managing waste, and advancing environmentally friendly utilities and operating systems. – Pg 43–44 Action 3.2, Environmental Engagement and Enrichment, addresses the need for full student participation by supporting unduplicated students so they can access the same enrichment opportunities as their peers. The focus is on hands-on learning experiences outside the classroom, enabling students to develop and apply knowledge through activities such as science camp participation and other enrichment programs. Progress is measured through student survey metrics. – Pg 48

gardening and native plant restoration program, along with an environmental pathways program to expose our students to the importance of
being shepherds of the land and environment. We hold our students to high academic standards and empower them as learners." - pg 4                                                                      "We also added field trip opportunities to this goal, to help give learning opportunities that may not be reachable for
some of our student population and included our sixth grade science camp in this section, along with our environmental field trips." - pg 10

The Coordinator will establish a district CTE Advisory Committee, directly support CTE and other pathways, and provide strategic planning and leadership for TK-12 articulation. In addition, the coordinator will align all CTE courses to CTE Model Curriculum Standards and expand early college credit options for pathway specific and career-connected post- secondary programs and pathways. Environmental Literacy are incorporated into this work. Communication about the Sonoma State promise and a-g requirements will be increased."

Parent and Family Participation (part of $3,000)
Parent and family participation will be promoted and encouraged throughout the year to promote a positive connection between school and home. This includes attendance at school activities such as parent-teacher conferences, student performances and events and sports events. Parents will be encouraged to be part of decision making committees such as the governing board, LCAP Parent Advisory Committee, Indian Education Committee, and PTO. Volunteering at the school in classrooms, in the school garden, and as coaches or tutors will all be encouraged. -Pg. 18

column33:
Action: School Garden
Need: Ongoing feedback from education partners identifies the need to maintain the school garden. Although our garden focuses on ag science and nutrition, cross-curriculum to other content areas such as language arts, math, science, social studies and art are often a part of the learning. Additionally, the garden is an excellent location to model sustainable practices and present environmental education lessons. Ongoing education partner feedback indicated that agriculture is a cornerstone area for learning based on our District location and prominent ag industry. Unduplicated students have family who work in this industry, aspire to be in agricultural fields of study, and find the learning in the garden to be preparing them for life skills.
The District will provide a school garden for outdoor learning experience for SED, EL, and Hispanic students. This experience for these students will give opportunities to developlanguage, help to make healthy eating choices,and give facilitate culturally relevant lessons. We will use the garden for all students that is a learning environment used to promote real world, hands on experiences LEA-wide.
-Pg. 111

column31:
Healthy Living ($2,500)
Promote a healthy and engaging lifestyle by providing instruction in nutrition, encouraging participation in community service, and expanding outdoor learning opportunities. An outdoor learning teacher will lead hands-on lessons in gardening and environmental education to support farm-to-table concepts and wellness-focused learning experiences. -Pg. 38
column33:
Future Projects: Outdoor Learning and School Garden
Effectiveness: Anticipated Impact
Looking ahead, the creation of a school garden and outdoor learning space is expected to offer enriching, hands-on experiences tied to environmental education and wellness. These planned initiatives align strongly with the goal of fostering a nurturing, sustainable, and stimulating educational environment for all students at Mupu. -Pg. 44
In alignment with Action 3.4, the completion of the school garden has been prioritized as a key initiative for promoting sustainability and healthy living. Support staff and parent volunteers will play a central role in providing hands-on garden-based learning experiences. Additionally, the school will encourage student leadership through green initiatives and sustainability-focused projects to foster student voice and environmental responsibility. - Pg. 45
